case_name: Managing Committee of Jai Narain College v. Appellant

facts.text: Appeal is C.A. No. 2 of 1972 by Special Leave from the judgment and order dated April 13, 1970 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 1074 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION C.A. No. 2 of 1972. Appeal by Special- Leave from the judgment and order dated April 13, 1970 of. the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 1074 of 1968.

facts.text: Appellant filed a writ petition before the High Court of Allahabad, Lucknow Bench, challenging the validity of a resolution passed on 12-11-1967 by the Managing Committee of the Jai Narain College, Lucknow, terminating his services.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed a writ petition before the High Court of Allahabad, Lucknow Bench, challenging the validity of a resolution passed on 12-11-1967 by the Managing Committee of the Jai Narain College, Lucknow, formerly known as Kanyakubja Degree College, an associated collegege of the Lucknow University, terminating his services, and praying for issue of an appropriate writ or order quashing the resolution.

facts.text: Learned single judge of Allahabad High Court quashed the resolution finding termination violated principles of natural justice and allowed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: A learned single judge of that Court, finding that in terminating the services, the Managing Committee acted in violation of principles of natural justice, quashed the resolution and allowed the writ petition.

facts.text: Managing Committee appealed to Division Bench of Allahabad High Court against single judge order.

anchor.surface_text: The Managing Committee appealed against the order. A Division Bench of the High Court found that the relationship between the College and the appellant was that of master and servant...

facts.text: Division Bench of Allahabad High Court set aside single judge order and dismissed writ petition on April 13, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The Bench, therefore, set aside the order of the learned single judge and dismissed the writ petition. It is from this judgment that the appeal has been preferred by special leave.

facts.text: Appellant joined service of the college as lecturer in 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant joined the service of the companylege as lecturer in 1946.

facts.text: Appellant was promoted to Head of the Department of Zoology in 1959.

anchor.surface_text: He was promoted to the post of Head of the Department of Zoology in 1959.

facts.text: Certain complaints against appellant received by Manager of College, charges framed, explanation called for.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of certain companyplaints against him received by the Manager of the College, charges were framed against him and his explanation was called for.

facts.text: Appellant submitted explanation to charges.

anchor.surface_text: He submitted an explanation.

facts.text: Explanation found not satisfactory, Managing Committee passed resolution on 12-11-1967 for removal of appellant from service.

anchor.surface_text: The explanation was found number to be satisfactory and the Managing Committee passed a resolution on 12-11-1967 for removal of the appellant from service.

facts.text: Jai Narain College formerly known as Kanyakubja Degree College, associated college of Lucknow University.

anchor.surface_text: Managing Committee of the Jai Narain College, Lucknow, formerly known as Kanyakubja Degree College, an associated companylege of the Lucknow University,

facts.text: Division Bench found relationship between College and appellant was master and servant.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the High Court found that the relationship between the College and the appellant was that of master and servant

facts.text: Division Bench found appellant given opportunity of submitting explanation, no violation of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: principle of natural justice was violated by terminating the services of the appellant as the appellant was given an opportunity of submitting his explanation to the charges.

facts.text: Appellant contended he had statutory status, services terminated in violation of Lucknow University Act, 1920 provisions.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. M. C. Setalvad, companytended that the appellant had a statutory status, that his services were terminated in violation of the provisions of statutes passed under the.Lucknow University Act, 1920

facts.text: Appellant contended not given reasonable opportunity to defend against charges.

anchor.surface_text: He further submitted that the appellant was number given a reasonable opportunity of defending himself against the charges.

facts.text: College governed by statutes 151, 152, 153 under Lucknow University Act, 1920.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant statutes governing this case are statutes 151, 152 and 153, framed under the provisions of the Lucknow University Act, 1920.

facts.text: Appellant entered into agreement when employed, Clause 5 provided for termination during probation or thereafter without notice if satisfied necessary for misconduct etc., provided opportunity to give explanation.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had entered into an agreement when he was employed in the companylege. Clause 5 of the agreement provided that the period of probation shall be one year unless extended by the Managing Committee and the College may at any time during the said period of probation put an end to this engagement, or if service shall companytinue beyond the said term, at any time thereafter, dispense with the services of the said Lecturer without numberice, if the Managing Committee of the said College is satisfied that it is necessary to remove the said Lec- turer for misconduct, insubordination or habitual neglect of duty on the part of the said Lecturer or in case any of the companyditions herein specified have been broken by the said Lecturer provided that an oppor- tunity is given to him by the said Managing Committee to give his explanation before a decision is arrived at.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no element of public employment, office or status capable of protection.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the decision in Vidyodaya University Council v. Silva 1  is companyrect or number, in this. case, we think there was numberelement of public employment, numberhing in the nature of an office or status which is capable of protection.

facts.text: Supreme Court held terms in Statute 151 have no force of law unless incorporated in contract.

anchor.surface_text: On a plain reading statute 151, it is clear that it only provides that the terms and companyditions mentioned therein must be incorporated in the companytract to be entered into between the companylege and the teacher companycerned. It does number say that the terms and companyditions have any legal force, until and unless they are embodied in an agreement.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Mathew, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Mathew, J.

facts.text: Division Bench held remedy is suit for damages, not writ under Article 226.

anchor.surface_text: even if the service of the appellant has been terminated in breach of the audi alteram partem rule of natural justice, the remedy of the appellant was to file a suit for damages and number to apply under Article 226 of the Constitution for a writ or order in the nature of certiorari

issues.text: Whether the termination of the appellant's services violated the principles of natural justice, particularly the audi alteram partem rule?

anchor.surface_text: finding that in terminating the services, the Managing Committee acted in violation of principles of natural justice, quashed the resolution and allowed the writ petition. The Managing Committee appealed against the order. A Division Bench of the High Court found that the relationship between the College and the appellant was that of master and servant and that even if the service of the appellant has been terminated in breach of the audi alteram partem rule of natural justice,

issues.text: Whether a writ or order in the nature of certiorari under Article 226 of the Constitution lies for termination of service in a master-servant relationship even if in breach of natural justice?

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the High Court found that the relationship between the College and the appellant was that of master and servant and that even if the service of the appellant has been terminated in breach of the audi alteram partem rule of natural justice, the remedy of the appellant was to file a suit for damages and not to apply under Article 226 of the Constitution for a writ or order in the nature of certiorari and that in fact no

issues.text: Whether the appellant possessed a statutory status such that termination in violation of university statutes would attract writ jurisdiction?

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant, Mr. M. C. Setalvad, contended that the appellant had a statutory status, that his services were terminated in violation of the provisions of statutes passed under the.Lucknow University Act, 1920 and, therefore the High Court was wrong in its conclusions that no

issues.text: Whether statutes 151, 152 and 153 framed under the Lucknow University Act, 1920 have the force of law proprio vigore or independent of incorporation in the contract of employment?

anchor.surface_text: In the case in hand, the position is entirely different. The relevant statutes governing this case are statutes 151, 152 and 153, framed under the provisions of the Lucknow University Act, 1920. Statute 151 provides that teachers of an Associated College including the principal shall be appointed on written contract and that the contract shall inter alia provide the conditions mentioned therein in addition to such other conditions not inconsistent with the Act and the statutes as an Associated College may include in its own form of agreement.

issues.text: Whether the Managing Committee, as a statutory body, acted in breach of a mandatory obligation imposed by statute in terminating the services?

anchor.surface_text: The Courts are also invested with the power to declare invalid the act of a statutory body, if by doing the act, the body has acted in breach of a mandatory obligation imposed by the statute, even if by making the declaration the body is compelled to do something which it does not desire to do.

issues.text: Whether a declaration that the contract of service still subsists or specific performance is available upon purported termination of a service contract?

anchor.surface_text: it is well settled that, when there is a purported termination of a contract of service, a declaration that the contract of service still subsisted would not be made in the absence of special circumstances, because of the principle that Courts do not ordinarily enforce specific performance of contracts of service see Executive Committee of U.P. State Warehousing Corporation Ltd. v. Chandra Kiran Tyagi 1  and Indian Airlines Corporation v. Sukhdeo Rai  .

anchor.surface_text: it is well settled that, when there is a purported termination of a contract of service, a declaration that the contract of service still subsisted would not be made in the absence of special circumstances, because of the principle that Courts do not ordinarily enforce specific performance

arguments.claim: In pure master-servant, termination valid if per contract; breach gives damages, not reinstatement; does not depend on hearing servant

anchor.surface_text: If the master wrongfully ends the contract, then the servant can pursue a claim for damages. So even if the master wrongfully dismisses the servant in breach of the contract, the employment is effectively terminated. In Ridge v. Baldwin

arguments.claim: Vidyodaya University v. Silva: University teacher under statute holds no office or status; no hearing required; ordinary master-servant contract

anchor.surface_text: A teacher appointed by a University constituted under a statute was held not to be holding an office or status in Vidyodaya University v. Silva. In that case the services of the respondent was brought to an end by a resolution of the University Council set up under the statute

arguments.court_reasoning: Followed as applicable here: no public element

arguments.claim: No element of public employment, office or status capable of protection in this case

anchor.surface_text: Whether the decision in Vidyodaya University Council v. Silva is correct or not, in this case, we think there was no element of public employment, nothing in the nature of an office or status which is capable of protection.

arguments.claim: Exceptions to no declaration rule: public servant contravening Art 311; industrial law; statutory body breach of mandatory obligation

anchor.surface_text: It is open to the Courts, in an appropriate case, to declare that a public servant who is dismissed from service in contravention of Article 311 continues to remain in service... The Courts are also invested with the power to declare invalid the act of a statutory body, if by doing the act, the body has acted in breach of a mandatory obligation

arguments.claim: Violation of statute/ordinance in affiliated college termination attracts Art 226 as they have force of law (citing Prabhakar Jodh)

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Setalvad contended that since the college in question is affiliated to a statutory body, namely, the University of Lucknow,and is governed by the relevant statutes and ordinances framed under the provisions of Lucknow University Act, 1920, any violation of the statute or the ordinance... In support of this, counsel relied upon the decision of this Court in Prabhakar Ramakrishna Jodh v. A. Pande

court_response_anchor.surface_text: The Court further said It is true that Clause 7 of the Ordinance provides that all teachers of affiliated companyleges shall be appointed on a written

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished: In Prabhakar, code had force of law independent of contract; here statutes require incorporation into contract, no independent force

arguments.claim: Statutes 151-153: terms must be incorporated in contract; no force of law proprio vigore

anchor.surface_text: On a plain reading statute 151, it is clear that it only provides that the terms and conditions mentioned therein must be incorporated in the contract to be entered into between the college and the teacher concerned. It does not say that the terms and conditions have any legal force, until and unless they are embodied in an agreement.

arguments.claim: Clause 5 of contract complied with: opportunity to explain given before decision

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had entered into an agreement when he was employed in the college. Clause 5 of the agreement provided... provided that an opportunity is given to him by the said Managing Committee to give his explanation before a decision is arrived at.

arguments.claim: No statutory body acting in breach of mandatory obligation; clause 5 has no statutory flavor as statute lays no dismissal procedure

anchor.surface_text: As already indicated, Statute 151 does not lay down any procedure for removal of a teacher to be incorporated in the contract So, clause 5 of the contract can, in no event, have even a statutory flavor and for its breach, the appellants remedy lay elsewhere.

holdings.text: In this case, there was no element of public employment, nothing in the nature of an office or status which is capable of protection.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the decision in Vidyodaya University Council v. Silva 1  is correct or not, in this. case, we think there was no element of public employment, nothing in the nature of an office or status which is capable of protection.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishing from cases like Malloch v. Aberdeen where public elements exist; here pure master-servant with no statutory support or office.

holdings.text: When there is a purported termination of a contract of service, a declaration that the contract of service still subsisted would not be made in the absence of special circumstances, because Courts do not ordinarily enforce specific performance of contracts of service.

anchor.surface_text: it is well settled that, when there is a purported termination of a contract of service, a declaration that the contract of service still subsisted would not be made in the absence of special circumstances, because of the principle that Courts do not ordinarily enforce specific performance of contracts of service

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying settled law from precedents like U.P. Warehousing Corp. v. Chandra Kiran Tyagi and Indian Airlines v. Sukhdeo Rai; exceptions do not apply here.

holdings.text: Statute 151 only provides that terms and conditions must be incorporated in the contract; they have no legal force until embodied in an agreement and have no force of law proprio vigore.

anchor.surface_text: On a plain reading statute 151, it is clear that it only provides that the terms and conditions mentioned therein must be incorporated in the contract to be entered into between the college and the teacher concerned. It does not say that the terms and conditions have any legal force, until and unless they are embodied in an agreement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain reading of Statute 151; contrasts with Prabhakar where code had independent force; here terms gain vitality only via contract.

holdings.text: The appellant was given an opportunity to submit his explanation to the charges; no principle of natural justice violated.

anchor.surface_text: principle of natural justice was violated by terminating the services of the appellant as the appellant was given an opportunity of submitting his explanation to the charges.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show charges framed, explanation called for and submitted but found unsatisfactory; complies with Clause 5 of contract.

holdings.text: Even if service terminated in breach of audi alteram partem rule of natural justice in master-servant relationship, remedy is suit for damages, not writ under Article 226.

anchor.surface_text: and that even if the service of the appellant has been terminated in breach of the audi alteram partem rule of natural justice, the remedy of the appellant was to file a suit for damages and not to apply under Article 226 of the Constitution for a writ or order in the nature of certiorari

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pure master-servant; no specific performance or writ; affirms Division Bench.

holdings.text: Clause 5 of the contract has no statutory flavor as Statute 151 lays down no procedure for removal to be incorporated; no breach of mandatory statutory obligation.

anchor.surface_text: As already indicated, Statute 151 does not lay down any procedure for removal of a teacher to be incorporated in the contract So, clause 5 of the contract can, in no event, have even a statutory flavor and for its breach, the appellants remedy lay elsewhere.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statute specifies no dismissal procedure; clause purely contractual; no mandatory obligation breached by statutory body.

anchor.surface_text: Indian Airlines Corporation v. Sukhdeo Rai  . If the master rightfully ends the contract, ,there can be no complaint.

precedents.case_name: Indian Airlines Corporation v. Sukhdeo Rai
precedents.cited_proposition: Courts do not ordinarily enforce specific performance of contracts of service

anchor.surface_text: In Ridge v. Baldwin 3 , Lord Reid said in his speech The law regarding master and servant is not in doubt. There cannot be specific performance of a contract of service

precedents.cited_proposition: Master can terminate contract of service at any time for any reason or none, but if not as per contract, damages for breach; does not depend on hearing the servant
precedents.cited_holding: The law regarding master and servant is not in doubt. There cannot be specific performance of a contract of service, and the master can terminate the contract with his servant at any time and for any reason or for none. But if he does so in a manner not warranted by the contract he must pay damages for breach of contract.

anchor.surface_text: Vidyodaya University v. Silva 1 . In that case the services of the respondent was brought to an end by a resolution of the University Council set up under the statute establishing the University.

precedents.cited_proposition: Teacher appointed by a statutory university does not hold an office or status; employment is ordinary master-servant contract; no right to hearing
precedents.cited_holding: The mere circumstance that the University was established by statute did not make contracts of employment other than ordinary master-servant contracts; no right to be heard.

anchor.surface_text: Recently the House of Lords considered the question in Malloch v. Aberdeen Corporation  2  . That case concerned a teacher in Scotland who was dismissed by the Education Committee

precedents.cited_proposition: Teacher holding office entitled to hearing before dismissal; master-servant test leads to illogical results; if public element or status, procedural requirements apply
precedents.cited_holding: The teacher had a right to be heard before dismissal as he was holding an office.

anchor.surface_text: On a plain reading statute 151, it is clear that it only provides that the terms and conditions mentioned therein must be incorporated in the contract to be entered into between the college and the teacher concerned. It does not say that the terms and conditions have any legal force, until and unless they are embodied in an agreement.
